metadata.case_name: Petitions under Article 32 (e.g., Petition No. 91 of 1957) and Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957

facts.text: Newspaper industry in India originally started as individual newspapers founded by leaders but developed into profit-making industry with big industrialists investing and combines controlling several newspapers.
Working journalists agitated for inquiry into wages, salaries, dearness allowance, retirement benefits, leave and conditions of service by impartial agency.
Uttar Pradesh Government appointed committee on June 18, 1947 to inquire into conditions of newspaper employees; Central Provinces Berar appointed Inquiry Committee on March 27, 1948.
Press Commission appointed September 23, 1952 under Chairmanship of Shri Justice G. S. Rajadhyaksha; report submitted July 14, 1954.
Press Commission found out of 137 concerns, 59 returned profits, 68 losses; overall profit about 6 lakhs on capital of 7 crores (less than 1% per annum).
Press Commission recommended minimum wage of Rs. 125 basic + Rs. 25 dearness allowance (total Rs. 150), division of localities for differential cost of living.
Press Commission recommended legislation for notice period, bonus, minimum wages, Sunday rest, leave, provident fund and gratuity.
Working Journalists (Industrial Disputes) Act, 1955 (1 of 1955) passed March 12, 1955 applying Industrial Disputes Act to working journalists.
Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955) received assent December 20, 1955.
Central Government constituted Wage Board by notification May 2, 1956 under s.8; Chairman Shri H. Divatia.
Wage Board decision published in Gazette of India Extraordinary Part II, Section 3 dated May 11, 1957.
Petitions under Article 32 filed challenging Act and Wage Board decision; Civil Appeals Nos. 699-703 of 1957 by special leave from Wage Board decision.
Wage Board classified newspapers on basis of gross revenue; considered multiple units or chains collectively.
Wage Board gave retrospective operation to decision; fixed scales for three years.
Wage Board did not consider capacity to pay of individual establishments or impact on industry.
Reconstitution of Board on retirement/resignation of member; decision by majority per rules published July 10, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Working Journalists (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 is ultra vires as it infringes fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14 and 32.
Whether the decision of the Wage Board is illegal, void and ultra vires the Act.
Whether the Wage Board exercised legislative, quasi-judicial or judicial functions.
Whether the Act and Wage Board decision impose unreasonable restrictions and direct burden on freedom of press and business.
Whether the Act is discriminatory under Article 14 by singling out newspaper employers and working journalists.

petitioner_arguments.text: Working Journalists Act, 1955 ultra vires as it infringes Arts. 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, 32; freedom of speech includes freedom of press and means to exercise it; Act fixes salaries disabling running of press.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 19(1)(a), 19(2); Ramesh Thapar v. State of Madras, 1950 SCR 594; Brij Bhusan v. State of Delhi, 1950 SCR 605

petitioner_arguments.text: Act violates Art. 19(1)(g) by placing unreasonable restraint on carrying on business; no consideration of capacity to pay; arbitrary criteria in s.9; no procedure laid down.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 19(1)(g), 19(6); Chintaman Rao v. State of MP, 1950 SCR 759; Dwarkadas Shrinivas v. Sholapur Spinning, 1954 SCR 674

petitioner_arguments.text: Act discriminatory under Art. 14; favours working journalists over other employees; singles out newspaper employers; one-sided binding under s.12, recovery under s.17.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 14; Britannia Bldg. & Iron Co. Ltd., 1954 1 LLJ 651

petitioner_arguments.text: Wage Board decision invalid: ultra vires Act, no reasons given, violated natural justice, arbitrary classification on gross revenue ignoring profits/losses, retrospective effect, exceeded power in fixing scales.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.9, s.11 Working Journalists Act; principles of natural justice; Thakur Raghbir Singh v. Court of Wards, 1953 SCR 1049

petitioner_arguments.text: Wage Board performed quasi-judicial functions like Industrial Tribunal; s.11 enabling but unreasonable if arbitrary procedure allowed.

respondent_arguments.text: Act does not infringe Arts. 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, 32; regulates conditions of service, not directly freedom of speech; pith and substance is industrial regulation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras, 1950 SCR 88; State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala, 1957 SCR 874

respondent_arguments.text: Wage Board performs legislative function, not judicial/quasi-judicial; wide discretion under s.9; considered all criteria; power to fix scales and retrospective effect.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.8-11 Working Journalists Act; Art. 43 Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: No discrimination under Art.14; working journalists distinct class requiring special legislation; reasonable classification.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar, 1955 1 SCR 1045

respondent_arguments.text: No requirement for reasons or audi alteram partem in legislative function; classification on gross revenue proper; capacity region-wise, not unit-wise.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England; Prentis v. Atlantic Coast Co., 211 US 210

respondent_arguments.text: Provisions like gratuity, hours of work, leave reasonable; follows Press Commission and fair wages committee.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Report of Committee on Fair Wages

court_reasoning.text: Petitions raise question of vires of Working Journalists Act, 1955 and Wage Board decision; common questions allow common judgment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To appreciate contentions, trace history leading to enactment.

court_reasoning.text: Detailed history: from state committees 1947-48, Press Commission 1952-54 recommending minimum wage Rs.150, enactment of 1955 Acts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act based on Press Commission recommendations, dropped 'minimum' during passage to fix proper wages.

court_reasoning.text: Act provisions: definitions, application of Industrial Disputes Act with modifications, retrenchment, gratuity, hours, leave, Wage Board under ss.8-12.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wage Board to consider cost of living, prevalent wages, regional circumstances, other relevant factors per s.9.

court_reasoning.text: Wage Board constituted May 2, 1956 with equal representatives and Chairman; Rules 1956 for procedure including majority decision.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proceedings continued after reconstitution on vacancy.

key_quotes.text: These petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise the question as to the vires of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Frames the core issue of the case

key_quotes.text: The Working Journalists Act, 1955, is ultra vires as it infringes the fundamental rights of the Petitioners guaranteed by the Constitution under Arts. 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14 and 32.
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Primary contention of petitioners on constitutional invalidity

key_quotes.text: The functions of the Wage Board constituted under s.8 of the Act were not judicial or quasi-judicial in character the fixation of the rates of wages by the Wage Board was a legislative act
key_quotes.speaker: respondent_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Respondent's key defence on nature of Wage Board functions
